@DogBoyBlue I think there can be. @TheAthleticTO is one example of trying it. But it requires reteaching audiences to pay for niche content.
"But Justin, you've developed certain beats," you say. Yeah, but I pursued those at 3am daily AND MOST PEOPLE HAVE LIVES/AREN'T CRAZY.
I worry and wonder...and the meantime, love the ones in Vancouver still plugging away. But we need more than generalists.
In Canada, there's still a business model for journos that do local breaking news, for federal politics, for trade pubs. For beat reporters?
Will those beats be replaced? Do papers have the resources to allow younger reporters the time to become experts in a subject anymore?
So many of the people who are leaving the Sun/Province are veterans with beats: soccer, university sports, immigrants, fed. politics, etc.
Lots of depressing things about the continued lobotomization of Postmedia papers, but one is the loss of specialized, impartial knowledge.
Aaaaaaand there goes the last reporter on Parliament Hill focused explicitly on B.C. issues. https://t.co/piF1Hugfcx
@jonnywakefield gotta divide up Fort St. John/Dawson Creek from the rest with tabs, and then change the x-axis range. Geez.

@Patmeister just Stats BC numbers. Projections for 2016 appeared to have come out recently: https://t.co/PFPNKiqzCn

The largest population increase in B.C. from 2011-2016?
Not in Metro Van: It's Langford, up 31.2%, followed by Fort St. John at 16.7%.
West Vancouver's population decreased by 4.7% in the last 5 years, the largest decrease for any B.C. city with at least 20,000 people.
@KamilKaramali this is an excellent way of ensuring I never help you again.
